intro: Silene quadridentata subsp. moehringiifolia, commonly known as the Moehring's four-toothed catchfly, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of North America. It is characterized by its small, pink to purple flowers and hairy, succulent stems that help it retain moisture in harsh environments. The subspecies is distinguished by its narrow, lance-shaped leaves and four stamens, which are typical of the Caryophyllaceae family. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in disturbed or open habitats. Due to its limited distribution and specific ecological requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species in some areas.
